posts.post_content:
It comes as no surprise to me that Mori's deack was so powerful in 2005 when he ran this dragon with Greater Good.  
  
Sacrificing Yosei to draw 5 cards then discard 3 during the opponent's upkeep, thereby shutting down that turn AND preventing the next turn's untap, was just such a powerful combo that few could recover.  
  
Also, Yosei was the most prominently featured Dragon in the Kamigawa novels, so that is a plus for players like me who love the flavor and feel of the game.
posts.html:
It comes as no surprise to me that Mori's deack was so powerful in 2005 when he ran this dragon with Greater Good.

Sacrificing Yosei to draw 5 cards then discard 3 during the opponent's upkeep, thereby shutting down that turn AND preventing the next turn's untap, was just such a powerful combo that few could recover.

Also, Yosei was the most prominently featured Dragon in the Kamigawa novels, so that is a plus for players like me who love the flavor and feel of the game.

I remember playing a Chord of Calling / Ghostway deck with tons of one-ofs, and thinking about a way to beat Yoseis since they tapped me out for too long. I beat the tournaments a few times after I found the solution in two Clones.
  
   
Kamigawa - Ravnica remains the best Standard I had to date.

posts.post_content: That's an exceptionally awesome dragon. All you have to do is tap 5 of their lands and they basically skip their next two turns, or you can tap down a creature or two and still most of their non basic lands. Reminds me of sleep, but built into a creature.

Posted By: lz17 (2/7/2010 12:43:37 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Time for a design story!  
  
As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); the spirit dragon cycle were costed according to how typical it was for dragons to show up in those colors.  
So [red](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=79242) and [blue](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=75286) were the most splashable, Yosei and [Cocopuffs](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=50445) less so, and [Jugan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=50247) the least so.
posts.html:
Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); the spirit dragon cycle were costed according to how typical it was for dragons to show up in those colors.
So red and blue were the most splashable, Yosei and Cocopuffs less so, and Jugan the least so.

Posted By: HairlessThoctar (2/6/2011 9:23:26 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Let's try a disgusting lockdown.
  
Take one part this thing, one part [Doomgape](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doomgape) and a pinch [Sheoldred, Whispering One](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sheoldred, Whispering One) or [Debtors' Knell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Debtors' Knell)   
   
The result is at the beginning of your upkeep you sacrifice old Yosei to [Doomgape](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doomgape) at the beginning of upkeep, then let [Sheoldred, Whispering One](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sheoldred, Whispering One) return it with little fuss. All the while tapping things. And NO UNTAP STEPS either!
  
   
Great reason to play B/W/G, and 5/5 from me :D
